channel.title: Gardens of the Roman Empire
channel.description: Recent content on Gardens of the Roman Empire

item.title: Arae Flaviae Large Building north of Forum
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Arae Flaviae Location Description This town on the Neckar river was granted municipal status around 84 AD or slightly later. In modern terms, it lies about halfway between Zurich and Stuttgart. Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Arae Flaviae Large Building north of Forum Keywords colonnades peristyles (Roman courtyards) Garden Description This building ca. 95 meters in width consisted of several units built at different times. These may represent more than one house, or they may be parts of one large house.

item.title: Andematunnum Tomb Garden of Anonymous Gaul
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Andematunnum Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Andematunnum Tomb Garden of Anonymous Gaul Keywords former reservoirs mausoleums orchards tombs Garden Description A famous inscription from the territory of the Lingonian Gauls (Langres) known only from a manuscript of the tenth century records the will of a local hunting enthusiast who built for himself a lavish mausoleum (cella memoriae) and equipped it with orchards (pomaria) and a reservoir (lacus) put in the care of two freedmen who are instructed to devote the revenues from them to upkeep of the tomb complex, and three landscape gardeners (topiarii) and their apprentices, each to be supported annually by the testator’s grandson, Sex.

item.title: Germania Superior
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description The regions on the upper Rhine formally became the province of Germania Superior, Upper Germany, during the reign of Domitian, probably around AD 85. Since the Augustan period, they had formed a military zone on the eastern fringes of Gallia Belgica and Gallica Lugdunensis. Moguntiacum (Mainz) at the confluence of the Rhine and Main rivers was the administrative capital and the site of a legionary base.

item.title: Urban house on Lungenstrasse (Colonia Claudia Ara Agrippinensium)
item.description: Province Germania inferior Location Colonia Claudia Ara Agrippinensium (Cologne) Location Description This large town on the west bank of the Rhine river was the civitas capital of the Ubii in the first half of the 1st century A.D. It was granted the status of colonia by Claudius in 50 and became the provincial capital in 85. Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Urban house on Lungenstrasse (Colonia Claudia Ara Agrippinensium) Keywords peristyles (Roman courtyards)

item.title: Germania inferior
item.description: Province Germania inferior Province Description The Augustan military zone along the lower Rhine was formally reorganized as the province of Germania Inferior, Lower Germany, during the reign of Domitian around A.D. 85. Until this time, the area had been on the eastern fringe of the province of Gallia Belgica. The provincial capital was Colonia Claudia Ara Agrippinensium (modern Cologne). Numerous legionary and auxiliary bases fortified the lower Rhine frontier throughout its history.

item.title: Romula Tomb Garden of Ael(ius) Iul(ius) Iulianus, Decurion
item.description: Province Dacia Traiana Province Description Location Romula Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Romula Tomb Garden of Ael(ius) Iul(ius) Iulianus, Decurion Keywords tombs epitaphs Garden Description A slab unearthed near Resça (Romula), Romania, in 1954 records a verse epitaph set up by Valeria Gemellina for her husband Ael(ius) Iul(ius) Iulianus, a decurion of the colony of Romula, some time probably in the later second or third century. In it she describes in pastoral terms well suited to the hexameter the setting of the “eternal home” (i.

item.title: Dacia Traiana
item.description: Province Dacia Traiana Province Description Dacia occupied the region occupied by today by Romania, Moldava, and parts of Bulgaria, Serbia, Hungary and the Ukraine. Homeland of the Gatae tribe, it was conquered by the Romans under Trajan in 106 CE. After the Romans retreated from this region in 271-275 CE, they renamed an area of Moesia Superior “Dacia Aureliana”. This entry concerns only original province of Dacia. The area was known to the Romans prior to its conquest, particularly for its position along the Hercynian Forest (Black Forest).

item.title: Sudeley/Spoonley Wood
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Sudeley/Spoonley Wood Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Sudeley/Spoonley Wood Rural Villa Keywords axial plan terrace gardens villae rusticae Garden Description The main residence of this rural estate in Gloucestershire, excavated in 1882, is of the winged corridor type (Fig. 1). From the north and south corners of the house, walls ran in a westerly direction to enclose an open courtyard (G in Fig. 1) approximately 65 meters wide and 45 meters deep from the outer boundary to the main entrance of the house.

item.title: Latimer Rural Villa
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Latimer Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Latimer Rural Villa Keywords fences (site elements) orchards villae rusticae Garden Description Excavations at this country house in Buckinghamshire have produced evidence for gardens adjacent to the main residence in its latest phase dating to the beginning of the 4th century (Fig. 1). The house at the west is of the winged corridor type, fronted by a large courtyard bisected by a paved central drive with a banked edge.

item.title: Gorhambury Rural Villa
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Gorhambury Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Gorhambury Rural Villa Keywords arbors axial plan loam villae rusticae Garden Description At this site in Hertfordshire near the town of Verulamium (St. Albans) excavations have revealed a multi-phased Roman farm, characterized in late Iron Age and Roman times by an outer courtyard with various service buildings and an inner courtyard in which the farm house stood (Fig. 1).

item.title: Gatcombe Rural Estate
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Gatcombe Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Gatcombe Rural Estate Keywords barrier walls Garden Description This site of a large rural estate about 9 hectares in size in Somerset is enclosed within a massive wall (Fig.1). Although the site was not completely excavated, there is evidence to suggest that the main residence (A in Fig. 1) was located at the southern end of the complex, separated from various workshops and subsidiary buildings in the northern half by an area of cultivated soil.

item.title: Frocester Court Rural Vila
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Frocester Court –> Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Frocester Court Rural Villa Keywords fences (site elements) orchards villae rusticae Garden Description This Roman villa in Gloucestershire is situated about 14 miles west of the civitas capital Corinium Dobunnorum (Cirencester). The main residence is of the winged corridor type, fronted by a large courtyard which was bounded by the house on one side, by a wall on the two sides perpendicular to the house and by a fence on the fourth side opposite the house (Fig.

item.title: Fishbourne Roman Palace
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Fishbourne Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Fishbourne Roman Palace Keywords colonnades palaces piscinae Garden Description Fishbourne Roman Palace was accidentally discovered during the digging of a water main trench in 1960. The discovery led to nine seasons of excavations (1961-69) that showed the site had developed from a military base at the time of the Roman invasion in AD 43 to a sumptuous palace by the end of the first century CE.

item.title: About
item.description: Gardens of the Roman Empire is a project created as part of the ISAW Library Summer Internship program. Editors June Dorsch Amartya Shri David Ratzan Christian Casey (Let’s put links in here to a list of edited articles or to an “about us” page.)

item.title: Eccles Rural Villa
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Eccles Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Eccles Rural Villa Keywords balnea piscinae villae rusticae Garden Description This country estate in modern Kent possessed a large ornamental pool (P in Fig. 1) in the area in front of the main residence (A in Fig. 1) and to the east of the attached bath house (Fig. 1). The masonry pool measuring 25 x 3.50 meters lay parallel to the house frontage.

item.title: Rustic villa at Blankenheim-Hülchrath
item.description: Province Germania inferior Location Blankenheim-Hülchrath Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rustic villa at Blankenheim-Hülchrath Keywords rural villas villae rusticae Garden Description This villa rustica was built on a slope so that the residential building (A on Plan 1) overlooked the rest of the lower lying farmyard (Image 1). The entire complex covered an area 120 m. in width and 250 m. in length (3 hectares). The house was separated from a large open area behind and to the southwest of it by a wall.

item.title: Darenth Rural Villa
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Darenth Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Darenth Rural Villa Keywords piscinae villae rusticae waterspouts Garden Description Excavations at this site of a Roman villa in Kent uncovered a large rectangular masonry pool in the courtyard, which was enclosed by buildings on the north, west, and east (Fig. 1). The villa buildings took up an area of 150 x 225 meters in total, including the courtyard with a width of 26.

item.title: Chester Tomb Painting
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Chester Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Chester Tomb Painting Keywords funerary buildings tombs Garden Description Toynbee’s suggestion that a military tombstone from Chester depicting a row of three gabled buildings with stylized trees or shrubs planted in front of the two at the sides perhaps represents a tomb garden with tomb and flanking funerary buildings, though plausible, cannot in itself be taken to show that tomb gardens existed in Roman Britain; it would, however, suggest that the concept of planting at tombs was regarded as conventionally Roman and appropriate.

item.title: Chedworth Rural Villa
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Chedworth Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Chedworth Rural Villa Keywords balnea mosaics (visual works) sherds villae rusticae Garden Description This Roman villa in Gloucestershire was partially excavated in the late 19th century, but only the built features and their mosaic floors appear to have been of interest to the Victorian diggers. Excavations in the courtyard conducted between 2000 and 2002 revealed that earlier excavators had not disturbed the courtyard.

item.title: Bancroft Rural Villa
item.description: Province «««< HEAD Britannia Britannia 017e4e671149596ab81dcaffc3351402c7a2fa95 Province Description Location Bancroft Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Bancroft Rural Villa Keywords balnea gazebos piscinae villae rusticae Garden Description Excavations between 1983 and 1986 at this site in Buckinghamshire revealed a Roman villa of the winged corridor type, which was built in the late 3rd century and rebuilt and enlarged in the mid-4th century (Fig.

item.title: Britannia
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description After Caesar’s campaigns in Britain in 55 and 54 BC, the southern part of the island lay within Rome’s sphere of influence. It was not until the Claudian invasion in 43 AD, however, that Britain was annexed as a Roman province, although the ‘conquest’ of Britain in the west and north continued and proceeded slowly in the decades thereafter. Apart from a brief interlude in the mid-2nd century, when the northern border of the province was fixed at the Antonine Wall in Scotland, from the 120’s the northern frontier of the island lay on Hadrian’s Wall stretching from the west to the east coast.

item.title: Camulodunum Suburban Gardens
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Camulodunum Location Description Camulodunum began as an Iron Age settlement defended by dykes, a combination of V-shaped ditch and rampart created by the upcast earth. It extended from the Roman river on the south to the Colne on the north, a distance of some four kilometers. Within this larger area, a legionary fort was built after the Claudian conquest of Britain in AD 43. On the site of the fort, a veteran colony was planted in about AD 49 and given the name Colonia Victricensis, City of Victory.
